facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 357 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 357 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 28, 1956 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 28, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  in Misc. Case No. 4 of 1955 and Civil Revision No. 189 of 1955,

facts.text: High Court cases arose out of order dated August 6, 1955 of Civil Judge Sitapur in Suit No. 16 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the order dated August 6, 1955 of the Civil Judge, Sitapur in Suit No. 16 of 1953.

facts.text: Respondent is a scheduled bank.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a scheduled bank, sued the appellant in the companyrt of the Civil Judge,

facts.text: Scheduled bank sued appellant in court of Civil Judge Sitapur Uttar Pradesh for recovery of money due under mortgage instrument.

anchor.surface_text: sued the appellant in the companyrt of the Civil Judge, Sitapore in Uttar Pradesh, for the recovery of money due under an instrument of mortgage.

facts.text: Appellant contested the suit on several grounds including entitlement to relief under Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act U.P. XV of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the suit on several grounds one of which was that he was entitled to relief under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act  U.P. XV of 1953

facts.text: The Act reduces the amount recoverable on a debt as defined in it.

anchor.surface_text: which reduced the amount recoverable on a debt as defined in it.

facts.text: Debt defined in the Act excludes debts due to scheduled bank.

anchor.surface_text: Now a debt was defined in the Act in these terms 2 f  debt means an advance in cash or in kind and includes any transaction which is in substance a debt but does number include an advance as aforesaid made on or after the first day of July, 1952 or a debt due to- the Central Government or Government of any State a local authority a scheduled bank

facts.text: Debt due to respondent scheduled bank is not a debt within the Act's definition.

anchor.surface_text: As the respondent was a scheduled bank the debt due to it from the appellant was number a debt within this definition

facts.text: Appellant contended definition excluding certain debts offends Article 14 of Constitution as arbitrary distinction denying equal protection.

anchor.surface_text: and companysequently, numberrelief would appear to be available to the appellant under the Act in respect of that debt. The appellant, however, companytended that the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts offended Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and denied the excluded debtors, the equal protection of the law

facts.text: Appellant applied to Civil Judge Sitapur under proviso to s.113 CPC to state case to High Court on invalidity of definition portion.

anchor.surface_text: This defence, therefore, raised a question as to the validity of a provision in the Act. So the appellant made an application to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, under the proviso to s. 113 of the Code of Civil Procedure asking him to state a case for the opinion of the High Court

facts.text: Civil Judge held impugned portion of definition invalid under Art 14 but not necessary for disposal as not severable, dismissed application.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge took the view that the impugned portion of the definition infringed art. 14 of the Constitution as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and was therefore invalid, but he held that it was number necessary for the disposal of the case to decide such question of invalidity because even if it was decided in favour of the appellant, the result would be to exclude the entire definition from the Act as the offending portion was number severable from the rest

facts.text: Appellant filed application to Allahabad High Court for revision of Civil Judge's order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then made an application to the High Court at Allahabad for a revision of the order of the learned Civil Judge.

facts.text: Appellant filed application to High Court under Article 228 of Constitution to withdraw case.

anchor.surface_text: He at the same time made another application to the High Court under Art. 228 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court dismissed revision application and Art 228 application by one judgment dated February 28, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disposed of both the applications by one judgment. ... From this judgment the present appeal has been filed.

facts.text: High Court held question of severability is construction of Act, not interpretation of Constitution, and not necessary for disposal.

anchor.surface_text: It held that there was numberdispute as to the companystitutional principle which was clear, namely, that every citizen was entitled to the equal protection of the laws and that any enactment which infringed that principle, is to that extent void, and that the only dispute was whether the impugned portion of the definition of a debt in the Act was severable from the rest and that was number a question of the interpretation of any provision of the Constitution but one of the companystruction of the Act itself.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 22, 1958 by SARKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. January 22. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held it is necessary to decide validity of impugned definition portion for disposal of case.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is hence allowed.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution. The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it

issues.text: whether the question raised comes within Art. 228 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution. The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it while Art. 228 of the Constitution has in view a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The definition excluding debts due to scheduled banks etc. offends Article 14 as it makes an arbitrary distinction between classes of debtors denying equal protection

anchor.surface_text: As the respondent was a scheduled bank the debt due to it from the appellant was not a debt within this definition and consequently, no relief would appear to be available to the appellant under the Act in respect of that debt. The appellant, however, contended that the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts offended Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and denied the excluded debtors, the equal protection of the law

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution. The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it while Art. 228 of the Constitution has in view a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution. Now the question raised in the present case is as to the validity of a provision in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act.

arguments.claim: It is necessary for disposal of case to decide validity of impugned portion of definition

anchor.surface_text: The point that really arises in this appeal is whether it is necessary for the disposal of the case to decide the question of the validity of a portion of the definition of a debt in the Act . All other conditions necessary for an order being made under the proviso to s. 113 of the Code or Art. 228 of the Constitution exist and as to this there is no serious dispute.

holdings.text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution. The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question concerns validity of Act provision, matching language of s.113 proviso.

holdings.text: This question is, however, also a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, for the validity of the provision is challenged on the ground that it contravenes an article of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it while Art. 228 of the Constitution has in view a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Challenge to provision's validity on constitutional contravention constitutes interpretation of Constitution for Art.228.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity question raised and pressed by appellant; cannot dispose case without deciding it; severability arises only post-invalidity finding.

holdings.text: The question as to the severability of the impugned part of the definition from the rest would arise only after it had been decided that the impugned part was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Without a decision of that question the case could not be disposed of. The fact that in the view of the court the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest and therefore in any view of the question as to the validity of the impugned part, the appellant would not get any relief, did not alter the position.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts improperly pre-judged severability assuming invalidity without first deciding validity; sequence requires validity first.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case. This appeal is hence allowed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed. Held that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution. The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it
We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case. This appeal is hence allowed.

The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it while Art. 228 of the Constitution has in view a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution.
We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case. This appeal is hence allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Without a decision of that question the case could not be disposed of. The fact that in the view of the court the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest and therefore in any view of the question as to the validity of the impugned part, the appellant would not get any relief, did not alter the position.
We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case. This appeal is hence allowed.
